body.p:
By rights I ought not to have noticed the report which reached me
respecting the hospital movement in baltimore?; for if people do not
choose to inform the conductors of Hebrew periodicals of their
doings, I do not see any necessity on the part of the conductors
of these to bother themselves about what has not been communicated
officiallyy. I really do not see the propriety in the people of
Baltimore ? hardly ever sending me a line respecting any thing
taking place among them; in this the reformer, the moderador and
orthodox are alike; it seems the Occident with its editor are of
no use to them. It is otherwise with the Israelite; this
blank edited by the gentlemanly of polished
blank has its favorite? in large numbers. If you
blank on the old proverb have I? “a fellow-feeling makes us
wondrous kind.” It is not joke what I say. I felt the reverse of
pleased to receive the first and only information of the hospital
movement from a person who had been in Baltimore, or rather from
one who heard it from another. They say “reported” to some and
some to me. It is not fair? and those who labor for the Israelit
in this country, if their treatment that blank mine
have another cause for complaint, nay disgust for the cruel neglec
with which they are uniformly treated.

But a truce to complaining, which I am certain will produce no
remedy. let me resort to your request ? retired
last evening at nine P. M. (your letter reached me at ½ p.5 P.M.
on Dr blank and he kindly lent me the accompanying volume, at
the same time stating that $4 would buy it. I thought the hint

about the price not very polite; while it is an offer, which you need
not mind however, as you can at your leisure return the book to
me, when I will restore it to it owner, It sounded however, like
Ephron's disinterestedness, in offering a piece of land for nothing
valued at 400 shekels; thought the present is only the
percent in greenbacks; a great difference truly.

I hope you may soon succeed in erecting a building of enough dimen
sions for all blank; since it is a cruelty to leave our
poor to the mercy of Christians who use all the means at their
command to affect conversions while they professedly attend to the
bodily wants of the sufferers. This has proved in America no
less than in Europe; and I rejoice therefore at every effort made to
lessen the evil.

Regarding a contribution of 5000Dollars from here; though stated
by you seemingly as a jest may prove a reality if the proper means
be resorted to tA? committee of your associates may with perfect
propriety propose joint action between Philadelphia & Baltimore, and
offer the former a share and vote in the management provided a
certain amount in subscription to the hospital fund and in sufficie
contribution to the annual expenses be secured here.My cooperation
in urging the plan you can calculate on; though I regret saty
of means. absence. had I the pecuniary ability to start a liberal
subscription, it could require no prompting to commence the work this
day. But I have little to give, I am as you are perhaps awre, engage
in anew enterprize, to form a publication fund, to print books as
far ar the contributions will reach. I have set up about 240 pages
of Miss G. Aguilar's Jewish Faith, and hope to complete the present
series of books sooner tha when the mechanics can be obtained
as at present they work so slowly that I know not how to promise a

completion of the works. From Baltimore as yet I have had no res
response only from Dr blank who writes that he cannot obtain any
aid for same. However I hope to come down after a while in person,
and then see what I can do. The idea, it strikes me is a good one,
as only when people are so to say partners in literary enterprizes
can they be induced to read, as they then do not want to lay out
their money without reaping the benefit.

Give my ? best regards to all at home, and accept the
assurance of my regard old for yourself and family.
